Early Access Review
								Oh su funi and random eks di eks di. Okay, the fun's over. Absolute rock bottom. Don't get me wrong, I don't mind stupid ways to have fun. I even found Goat Simulator (at least slightly) amusing, because - say what you want about it, but it clearly included some work being done, the city was filled with easter eggs, stuff to do, there were achievements, workshop support, etc. The developer is claiming that this is not trying to be Goat Simulator, but I'm absolutely sure this piece of software tried to go the same way while completely missing the point, offering no fun, basically no gameplay and failing at being funny.The developer of this piece software completely misuderstood the point of Goat Simulator and thought that [insert random word here] Simulators are funny, because they are poorly made and you can't do anything there. Also making this type of "simulator" now is not even beating a dead horse, because the horse has been dead for half of the year, it's basically beating a horse skeleton now. I guess that developer decided to download Unity 3D and tried to put something together in it. Nothing against him, but you can clearly see he has absolutely no idea what he is doing. The menu is barely working, "Exit Game" button in the main menu doesn't work at all, other buttons in some game mods are bugged as well. Anyway let's get to the point. The game has four game mods. So let's do this, shall we?ClassicFirst mode is called Classic. The first thing you will notice is a mouse cursor visible while playing, but it goes away when you click the mouse button. Second thing you will notice is absolutely insane performance. I have about 10-15 FPS on this small map on the fastest settings. On a small map with some grass and few ridiculously small cows randomly placed there. I would seriously like to know the reason of it being more hardware demanding than Crysis. I have two theories. First is that the physics (this is using PhysX, or at least it was installing it) is badly coded, second theory is that it's because there are like thousands of trees on the edge of the map. If you go too far, you die instantly and go back. But I found out that if you hold W and you keep holding it while dying, you just get back up and you can continue with your journey for self-discovery. The cows are stuck in 2 seconds long animation and you can even see when they are reseting. You have some weapons, which are absolutely pointless anyway, because there is nothing to shoot with them, except the ground, which is something, I guess? If you shoot the cow, nothing happens. There are bullet decals, but they are levitating in the air, because cows have invisible square hitboxes around them. Another thing is that these guns are stock default Unity guns I had pleasure to see in another awesome piece of software known as Air Control, and trust me, I would like to be joking. There are few round collectables on the ground that can be collected that will make you move faster or will slow down a time. I remember them from Air Control as well, so I think these things are included in Unity, or maybe in its Pro version. Well, that's the first mode for you anyway, let's move to the second one.GrassYou... do nothing there, you can move the camera around and watch model of grass moving upwards from the ground. Su randum! Also there is a sketch of corn. It's not even modelled, it's just 2D picture with two colours used. Okay, that's the grass mode. This mode has bugged menu, because when I tried to click the button to go back to Main Menu, it didn't do anything, so I had to shut it down to be able to "play" another mode. Now let's skip to it!DubstepCuz you know, if you have no idea what to do, put dubstep there. In this mode there is just a very small map (with fence being the border) with some lights, dubstep music playing there and the cows rotating around. Comedy gold! The terrain is glowing and sky is moving. I guess it's hardcore party. There is one hipster cow that's not part of the crowd. This cow is flying, changing the scale, etc. I thought: "Wow, developer can scale a cow model, impressive!"RangeI think that Range mode is supposed to be shooting mode, but to be honest, it doesn't work for me, so I guess it's broken. There is nothing happening when I load it. When I press Escape, I bug through the ceiling and fall on the ground and then... still nothing. Keys on my keyboard aren't doing anything and mouse as well, so I couldn't move and couldn't even move camera around. I guess you can use this mode as a wallpaper.So that's Grass Simulator for you! Su funi! "But it's in Early Access!", you could say and the developer is promising another features added in the future. That's right, but look, there are good and promising games in Early Access that are only getting better and then there is this thing which obviously will never be good, because the developer is lacking developing skills and the whole idea of Grass Simulator is stupid to begin with. I would like to be proven wrong, but I don't think I will. For me, the biggest problem with this software is that skilled person would be able to make it in a day and amateur in few days with help of some YouTube tutorials. The most baffling thing is that this is being sold for actual money. It could be okay as a some learning project for developer on some website where you could play it in the web browser, but it's not okay as a product on Steam being sold for actual money. Especially for 8,99€ (10% off). I find this price absolutely ludicrous and mocking all the people who bought this for full price, because you can get Skyrim for lower price when it's on sale. Last message is for bunch of internet "comedians" making the same tired jokes in their reviews - we've already seen it milions of times, so you are not funny nor original, also you're giving it bigger score (Mostly Positive at the time of writing this review) that could mislead some people into thinking that this is actually something good.

												Although this game was very entertaining and very fun to play for ten minutes, all in all, based upon the content, it's a waste of money. It doesn't cost much, no, but you do have better games for the same price to spend your money on.Classic Mode:Has no objective at all. You walk around in a reasonably small world filled with a single cabin, grass, fences, trees and cows with buggy heads. Shooting the cows makes them explode but once you've seen that once and you've giggled - do you want to see it again?Grass Mode:Why would you even put this into a game? You don't spend money on a game to watch grass grow. You can't move or equip anything. All you do is sit in your chair and watch grass grow. Paint-Drying simulator will be the next release.Dubstep Mode:I laughed for about six miliseconds. Stingy cow animations with some tacky lighting effects and some terrible dubstep music. Putting two-and-two together, yes, it's just spinning cows dancing to music. Done.Ranged Mode:Um, this is meant to be a "Grass Simulator", not a FPS. Completely irrelevant to the game, and once again has no clear objective. The mace is pointless; you can't kill cows with it and you can't actually get out of the cabin that you spawn in on this mode.Snowfall Mode:This mode is the only one which actually has detail. Probably my favourite mode because the map is actually extremely well modeled, but much like the Classic Mode, has no objective whatsoever. Just walking around in a snowy place with, oh! Guess what! Cows!At first I thought it was a direct model from KHOLAT.Bad Party Mode:This mode does one thing, and one thing only. Generate lag. Guess what! Cows again! Superspeed cows with lights hanging off their backs and dying. For people to laugh at that they really must have a bad sense of humour. Sorry, but why would you put things like that in a game, especially since people actually paid money for this?Online Mode:Gah, what do I say about this? Like I said before, if you call a game "Grass Simulator", you must be mad to turn it into an FPS. People seem to be invincible, the aiming sucks, the bobbing of the weapons, although it's realistic, makes it extremely difficult to see what you're doing.All In All, this game is just a waste of money. This game would be perfect if it was a Free to Play game and is very good at pointlessly consuming 20 minutes of your life. You're better off just watching videos of this game and saving your money.

												In its current state, this game is not worth getting. There are several modes, but not really anything to do in most. You'll be lucky to squeeze 1-2 hours out of it. The multiplayer mode is useless, as there are never any lobbies open. You can create one, but no one is ever online to play. Additionally, the performance is poor. Alone on a multiplayer map with graphics on 'Fastest' I get marginally better FPS than Battlefield 3 with 64 players on Intel graphics. The guns feel and sound weak, though they are vastly improved from the single player guns. The controls can be painfully awkward and are not rebindable. To quit multiplayer I have to Alt+Tab and close it as I cannot find an option to return to the menu or quit the game.  Finally, the Grass Simulating mode has the worst graphics of any mode, featuring 2D 'sprites' rather than 3D models of grass (this is most noticeable with the green silhouette of corn.)Despite the updates the game has received, essentially no significant improvements to individual modes have been made as far as I can tell. New modes get added, and nothing gets fixed. Despite a HUD and all guns being fully animated in multiplayer, the single player modes still have unfinished animations for guns and no hud at all.Perhaps someday, if the dev is willing to fix and expand existing modes instead of randomly adding new ones, the game may end up ok. However, until that day comes I advise you stay clear of Grass Simulator.\\V0.2.1 Update:Just performance fixes and maybe(?) some bugfixes. No new content. Multiplayer still ugly and empty (fun fact: it's impossible to use up all your ammo in a match.)  At least if you now find yourself playing Grass Simulator it will run better.V0.2.2 Update:MAIN MENU BUG FINALLY FIXED. You can properly change game modes now. Unless you start multiplayer, then you have to restart the game. :/New mode, Hellfire, replaced the 'Grass' mode. It's effectively 'Classic' mode but with f.lux set to darkroom and some reskinned guns. Also, and I believe this is new in this version, weapon recoil is more severe. Weirdly, only the gun model moves-your bullets still go to the same spot and the camera fails to move, creating a weird look. I noticed the Glock sounds like it has a suppressor in Hellfire mode, and Classic, Hellfire [and I assume Snowfall as well] now have infinite ammo for all guns. The infinite ammo was implemented incorrectly, however, and you now never need to reload. Cow hit boxes are wrong as well.While it was nice to see an update that actually addressed problems and attempted to add 'new' content, I still cannot recommend this game to anyone.

												There exist numerous bad reviews for this game, but I thought I'd try it for myself. I am not one of those people who blast a game after playing it for 35 minutes, but trust me on this one, in 35 minutes I checked out every single thing this game had to offer. There is no story, no intro, no video, no cutscene, no dialog at all. Just the obnoxious music at the start screen. You start Classic mode, to find yourself in a random field with cows (wooden, low geometry idle models) grazing grass made up of 2-D models that will remind you of Midtown Madness (the 1999 game by MS). If you name a game Grass Simulator, for the love of Cthulhu, at least render the freaking grass nicely! And to think that THIS maxed out my decent laptop system at second-best graphics quality (fell below 30fps). What is it using the memory for? Definitely not rendering anything in the game!Okay, so you're in the field. Now what? You have a crosshair in the center of the screen - that's all. Since this is obviously not your first game, you click around buttons, and realise that number keys bring up different weapons. You can shoot cows with a Glock, an old-timey Revolver, a Tommy-Gun, and apparently what looks like a swinging mace. After 3-4 bullets the cows explode. That's it. The worst part, is that the budgeoning mace ironically does no damage. The "world", i.e., the random field, has invisible borders you can't cross (but your bullets can) and there is no map, no HUD, nothing at all that can tell you where you are and what, if anything, are you supposed to do. Oh, and there are no Ammo indicators, it just runs out when it wishes.Next is the "Grass" mode, where you can be a strand of grass on the ground, and can see the Sun set and rise every few seconds, seeing up close the pathetic 2-D grass models around you grow in height as days go by. I don't know if this bit was some satire on the overdose of crappy, mindless simulator games flooding social media, but this is truly pointless. Also, satire works best if there is something of use to complement it. Someone tell that to the Devs.Then there's a Dubstep mode, where some groovy music plays and you have cows spazzing in circles about their fixed axes. You can just watch the light-and-sound show, walk around and watch cows flashing in bright colours rotating to trippy music that repeats every 2.5 mins. The Bad Disco mode is a worse version of the same, with series of glowing disco lights replaced by the cow models. Frankly, seeing this does give you a laugh for the first 20 seconds, but after the joke is over you kinda wonder why the hell this game existsThe Snow Forest is actually a decent-looking stage which again clearly shows that the trees are much better-designed than the grass. Again, you have guns and you shoot cows to explode them.My absolute crappy experience was the Range: There are targets for you to shoot. That's it. No count, no score, no ammo indicator.Throughout the game's various levels, you:-Can't switch to guns if you die. Gotta reboot the game (oh yes!);-May randomly just die, while walking or standing (I even died randomly in the Range); of course, no guns IF you manage to respawn;-Exploding cows, if too close to you, push you back and their explosions are lethal (no health bar whatsoever);-Might face a simple crash;-Might face the game's level loading but you freezing, with the Menu still functional.I had chanced upon this game in Greenlight, and voted yes because the idea seemed new, hilarious and really satirical. But the game has absolutely nothing in it. I expected something like Goat simulator, maybe. What I got was an 800 MB download that basically consisted of 2 MP3 files, 2 terrain models, 1 animal model, 4 weapon models, 2 tree models and maybe 5-6 grass PNGs. I later came to know that if the game got through Greenlight, the Devs would gift a key to those in the group following the game. They did not ask anyone to promote the game in any way, and the group was closed, so I don't know how ethical this whole deal was, but I am pretty sure that shady releases like these are a major reason why the Greenlight system got shut down. If I am feeling so bad over spending less than an hour, and a little bandwidth, I cannot imagine the plight of those who shelled out 10 Euros for this piece of absolute defecation.

												You know how Goat Simulator started as a joke and then became one of the best games ever?Well, this is kinda like that; except that instead of trying to simulate a goat the Devs tried to simulate the grass really well.To be fair, it is really damn good grass... from a distance. The pure visual experience of this "game" is worth checking out when it's on sale. Up close, it's just another basic system of models with "photographic quality' textures that don't scale well, so you can see all the ugly stretching and pixellation when you take a really close look at the grass at your feet.But the idea here is to stare out over a vast field of grass, so I can forgive the fact that it's not up to the microscope inspection test.It's really not a GOTY candidate, in fact it's nothing special at all. It's one element of the background from just about every other game, which has been taken to the extreme. In a funny, roundabout way, that makes it interesting; although I wouldn't say it's particularly compelling.Would I buy it for $5? Never. For 99c on sale? Maybe. 												Grass Simulator takes place back in the 70's where it was common for 'hippies' to try and stand up for their land during an era where it was common for industrialists to turn nature places into buildings and factories that made the business man alot of money. This is a story driven RPG where your choices matter. You play as a character created person trying to keep the land that you grew up in with a group of your friends/foes as a business man by the name of Daniel Davies who owns the multi-billionare corporation: 'Davies Inc' wants to turn the memory rich land into a profitable cookie factory. Its up to you to stop him as you are introduced to the sprawling open world of the land you are trying to protect and the towns surrounding it as you can either stop Davies by gaining power or doing underground illegal work. Either way gives a completely different story with more choices branching out from there. This game also has a heavy focus on weed or as its known 'grass' in the game as every day in the game you have the choice to take the 'grass' and boost your stats but slowly your character is losing its stats and dying or you can choose to not take 'grass' which will leave your character with small stats but will gain immensly as you keep choosing not to take it. Hence the title of this name. Other than the protagonist and the antagonist there are other side characters who are very unique and almost make this game. These characters include Charles Heathbar; your boyfriend or Charlie Heathbar who is your girlfriend (you choose). There is also your best friend Piccolo as you can decide to whether hide his alien identity or keep it public and of course your inside source on 'Davies Inc', Louis Litt. He was easily the best character and made me feel for everyone in the game. Do you know what also made me feel for everything in the game? The beatiful graphics that almost made me feel I was in a real world and of course the sheer scale of this world I was in. It is huge covering the small American towns around you and as you go through the game slowly unlocking the whole of North America and when you complete the mains story you get the endgame of South America where there is promised to be DLC and more quests there. Overall, this game is amazing and is a must play to anyone who has a PC.Pros:+Beautiful Graphics+Story changes every time+Large open world+Amazing characters+Made me feel for the land+Ending made me cryCons:-The story is a little too long with it clocking around 200 hours. But thats just the main story and there are over 9000 side quests.This game shows what happens when you really try to pull of an amazing game and the only con isn't even a con.11/10

												Since I was a young child, I was crippled with an allergy to grass. I used to spend my weekends sitting mournfully on my windowsill as my friends played out in the fields.My mother even installed a plastic lawn around our house so I could play without fear of dying, but the experience was too false as the lawn could not simulate the true freedom of a field.Eventually I sunk into depression and decided to commit suicide by playing in the field that my friends had invited me to all those years ago. I did not get far before my body had completely shut down from exposure. Luckily I was found and managed to reach a hospital before the exposure managed to kill me. Upon recovery I was under 24-hour surveillance to ensure I did not go near the field again - a fact that plunged me into depression even further. It was upon the 2nd of April, 2015 that I planned to take my life again where, by luck, I noticed the release of "Grass Simulator" on Steam. Fearful it would not match my preconceptions of grass, I bought and installed the game.Grass Simulator provided me a rich and beautiful simulation of how playing in the fields was to my friends and, I daresay, saved my life. So I thank the creator of this game. You have saved my life, but think of how many others you have saved, who have not spoken up. Thank you. Grass Simulator - 10/10

Early Access Review
								I wanted to make this review short and sweet, but it's hard to stop writing, even when excluding facts that could potentially contaminate an exceptionally well thought-out gaming experience. There's just so much to say.Grass Simulator is, simply put, the best single-player games ever released for the PC. It does so many things right in so many ways that it might be possible to write a thesis on the topic of Grass Simulator compared to other games. What Daniel Davies has created is simply a masterpiece -- a work of art in the genre. Not only does it engage the mind with mysterious happenings, vagaries, and mostly intelligent dialogue, but also captures the senses with a superb visual style made possible by brilliant technology. And once the initial shock of it all wears off and it becomes possible to peel back the polished layers of sight and sound, there is an excellent FPS here. Grass Simulator doesn't do anything particularly new; it doesn't really innovate in many ways. But what it does is set a new height for all other designers of video games to reach. It still isn't exactly perfect, but it's about as close as I've seen.

Product received for free
												I saw a group for this game while in development stating that a giveaway of keys would take place on we had enough members or something. I joined up because the premise was silly as hell. With all of the "simulation" genre taking off, it appeared a good goof was in order. That's what this game is, an elaborate joke that will cost other people money to be in on it. I know other simulators were around that goofed (Surgeon Sim, Goat Sim) and were great to play. This game was limited in scope and touted the "best" level as a bunch of cows spinning and flying to dubstep.Have there been updates? Yes. Not many, not a lot of content aside from different dubstep and tree textures. Is this a game? No. You can't add a gun and leave out story/objective and be a game.Is it a simulator? I'd say yes, if the mechanic was really a zen environment where you sat around as grass and blew in the wind, like a paid for screensaver/sound machine. Is it fun? No. Shooting cows with limited ammo and watching them explode on death is a lot like adding god mode to a game and skipping cutscenes and dialogue. There is no fun to be had when the fun is limited to "stand still, listen to dubstep, shoot exploding cows if you feel like it, whatever. we don't care."I would recommend buying this for a gag gift, but you'd probably have more fun with a fake lottery ticket.
